awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   P2C2:   Combining glacier and paleolake records to limit Latest Pleistocene climate change in the northern Great Basin
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaboration between professors and students at North Dakota State University and Middlebury College will reconstruct changes in climate and surface water in the southwestern United States between 20,000 and 11,500 years ago. These changes caused glaciers and lakes to expand during the last glaciation, and then disappear entirely as climate warmed.  Reconstructing the climatic conditions that drove this behavior will yield important information about how quickly climate and resulting surface water resources can change, which will improve projections of future surface water changes under a warming climate.

The magnitude and pace of temperature and precipitation changes in the southwestern United States at the end of the last glaciation have been difficult to resolve.  This project will use a new approach that has shown promise in smaller-scale applications.  Glaciers and lakes respond to changes in temperature and precipitation with differing sensitivities.  Studying geologic records of former glaciers and lakes simultaneously, therefore, provides the opportunity to identify the relative roles of temperature and precipitation in driving glacier and lake behavior.  This project will combine field-based geologic data with computer modeling to quantify changes in temperature and precipitation during the last episode of major climatic change in the southwestern United States.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This study improved the understanding of how climate changed during the transition from the end of the last glaciation (ice age) to the current warm period in the northern Great Basin region, which includes Nevada and Utah of the southwestern United States. This transition occurred from 19,000 to 11,500 years ago, featuring global climate shifts and significant environmental change. In the Great Basin, the climate shift caused small glaciers to disappear from most mountains and large lakes to diminish or disappear from neighboring valleys. By examining sediments and landforms in the northern Great Basin, this study generated important new time limits on the pace and magnitude of climate change during a critical interval of Earth history.

            A key outcome of this study includes a history of glacier change across the northern Great Basin, spanning the time when mountain glaciers reached their maximum size during the last glaciation to the time when glaciers disappeared. This study used the rare isotope beryllium-10, which forms in sediment deposited along the edge of past glaciers, to determine when glaciers last existed and how quickly they disappeared. The ages of these sediments reveal two intervals of glacier culmination, first at ca. 21,000-19,000 years ago and again at 18,000-16,000 years ago, with each interval representing a climate cold enough and/or wet enough to support glaciers in the tallest mountains. Subsequently, glacier lengths reduced by 50-75% by 15,000-13,000 years ago, and then disappeared by 12,000-11,000 years ago. This glacial history provided the framework for reconstructing changes in climate that accompanied glacier culmination and subsequent disappearance.

            A second key outcome of this study is a product of research that modeled changes in the size of glaciers and lakes through time using computational methods. The model experiments simulated known glacier extents in 1-3 mountain ranges and known lake extents in 1-2 valleys during three distinct time intervals spanning 21,000 to 11,000 years ago. Modeling both glaciers and lakes yielded a narrow range of possible climatic conditions in which glaciers and lakes could coexist, defined by a combination of temperature and precipitation. Climatic conditions during the first phase of glacier culmination (21,000-19,000 years ago) featured temperatures 10-12°C colder than modern with accompanying precipitation near that of modern climate. During the second phase of glacier culmination (18,000-16,000 years ago), climate was 7.5-10.5C colder with 50% more precipitation than modern. This increase in precipitation during the latter time interval is reflected by the presence of larger lakes in the northern Great Basin and likely resulted from strengthening northwesterly airflow into the region during winter months. During the interval 13,000-11,000 years ago when glaciers were retreating and lakes were declining (but still larger than present), climate was 5.5-7.5C colder with 20-80% more precipitation than modern. Together, these findings indicate persistent cold conditions in the northern Great Basin from the interval 21,000-16,000 years ago, with precipitation near or greater than modern amounts. The transition from the last glaciation commenced throughout the Great Basin ca. 15,000 years ago with the decline of glaciers and lakes and attendant warming of 3-5C.

Broader Impacts

The study supported training of two graduate students who earned Master of Science degrees and four undergraduates who earned Bachelor of Science degrees at North Dakota State University. Students gained experience in the study of sediments and landforms deposited by glaciers and lakes, including field mapping and chemical analysis of rocks. Students also gained experience representing data in geographic information systems, which enabled the reconstruction of glaciers and lakes during intervals of geologic past. Students participating in the study presented the results of different components of the research at professional conferences, in thesis documents, and in published journal articles. Published products are freely available by request from the Principal Investigator.

            Research activities permitted mentoring opportunities for two graduate students, both working with undergraduate students on various aspects of the study. Graduate students trained undergraduates in laboratory and modeling components of the study and in the preparation of scientific presentations at professional conferences. Graduate students earned valuable experience as mentors and undergraduates learned the benefits of challenges of graduate level research in Earth science.

            Finally, products of the research, including some still in development, have been shared with staff members at Great Basin National Park, providing useful information natural history for park visitors. This includes a map of glacial deposits and landforms in the park and a description of glacial and climate history of the Great Basin.
